column1: Indian Railways (IR) is India's national railway system operated by the Ministry of Railways. It manages the fourth largest railway network in the world by size
column4: 861 mi) and total track length of 121
column6: 439 mi) as of March 2017. Routes are electrified with 25 kV AC electric traction while 33% of them are double or multi-tracked.Indian Railway (IR) runs more than 20
column8: on both long-distance and suburban routes
column10: 349 stations across India. The trains have five-digit and four-digit numbering system. Mail or Express trains
column12: run at an average speed of 50.6 kilometres per hour (31.4 mph). Most premium passenger trains like Rajdhani
column13: Shatabdi Exp run at peak speed of 140–150 km/h (87–93 mph) with Gatiman Express between New Delhi and Agra touching peak speed of 160 km/h (99 mph). Indian railways has also started a pilot project by the name of "Train-18"
column14: with successful trials between Delhi-Varanasi and Lucknow-Delhi and clocked maximum track speed of 180 km/h (112mph). In the freight segment
column16: 200 trains daily. The average speed of freight trains is around 24 kilometres per hour (15 mph). Maximum speed of freight trains varies from 60 to 75 km/h (37 to 47 mph) depending upon their axle load with container special running at a peak speed of 100 km/h (62 mph).
